Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Ecological genomics of local adaptation in a perennial plant species
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will contribute to a growing body of work concerned with the genetic basis of adaptation. Adaptation to local environments is important for persistence under a changing climate; however, remarkably little is known about the genetic mechanisms by which it occurs. This work will examine the genetic underpinnings of local adaptation in a perennial plant species with two well-studied, putatively adaptive genes that are associated with chemical defense against herbivores. The researchers focus on white clover, an important grazing crop. The research promotes collaborations between three U.S. research institutions and a New Zealand agricultural research institute. It also builds upon the previously established Clover Project, which has provided instructional materials to > 70 teachers and 6000+ students nationwide. This project helps train an underrepresented minority student and will provide independent, complementary projects for 6+ undergraduate students. Because the focal plant species is an important agricultural crop worldwide, the development of genetic resources will be useful for breeders.

This research will examine the genetic underpinnings of local adaptation in white clover (Trifolium repens L.). For two years, reproductive output will be measured for cloned plants grown in reciprocal common gardens across three climatically distinct sites. QTL mapping of fitness measurements will characterize the genetic architecture of local adaptation. Research will determine the distribution of effect sizes of locally adaptive genes and the extent that adaptation is caused by either conditionally neutral alleles or ones that show antagonistic pleiotropy. Overall the work will provide a genome-wide assessment of the importance of cyanogenesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work contributes to a growing body of research concerned with identifying the genetic basis of adaptation to different climates, which informs conservation and crop improvement efforts. It promoted research collaborations between three US research institutions (Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Minnesota – Duluth, and the University of Florida). This project was invaluable for the co-PI's progress as a science educator and provided independent, complementary projects for three undergraduate students at two universities, as well as training in essential laboratory skills for an additional 12 students, including 4 high school students. It built upon an ongoing science outreach program developed by the PI’s lab that has provided classroom kits and curricular materials to > 100 teachers and 8000+ students nationwide. Additionally, the focal species (white clover) is an important forage crop, so genetic resources developed herein will be useful for breeders.

Adaptation to local climates is important for persistence across varying climates.  However, remarkably little is known about the genetic mechanisms by which local climatic adaptation occurs. This work examined the genetic basis of climatic adaptation in white clover, which shows natural variation in a chemical defense against herbivores. Plant growth and reproduction were measured for three years three climatically distinct sites. Genes that contributed to high reproductive output were identified for each site to characterize the genetic architecture of adaptation across sites.  The relative fitness contributions of the two known herbivore defense genes, compared to other genetic factors, were assessed. Preliminary results indicate that herbivore defense genes do not appear to greatly affect survival or reproduction; however, there are several genetic regions that do. In particular, one gene appears to show trade-offs across climates, such that one version of the gene promotes reproduction in Florida, while the other version of the gene promotes survival in Minnesota.
